conclusion: To determine the amount of heat exchanged during a cyclic process, we need to calculate the net work done by the gas over one complete cycle and use the first law of thermodynamics.
The first law states that the net heat exchanged Q is equal to the net work done W: Q = W.
The process is a closed loop (cycle) on a PV diagram.

premise: The process is a closed loop (cycle) on a PV diagram.
conclusion: We need to calculate the work done in each segment of the cycle and sum them up.
Segment AB represents an isobaric (constant pressure) process from V1 to V2 at pressure P2.

premise: Segment AB represents an isobaric (constant pressure) process from V1 to V2 at pressure P2.
conclusion: Work done in segment AB is W_AB = P2 (V2 - V1).
Segment BC represents a constant volume (isochoric) process from V2 to V1.

premise: Segment BC represents a constant volume (isochoric) process from V2 to V1.
conclusion: Work done in segment BC is W_BC = 0.
Segment CD represents an isochoric (constant volume) process from P2 to P1.

premise: Segment CD represents an isochoric (constant volume) process from P2 to P1.
conclusion: Work done in segment CD is W_CD = 0.
Segment DA represents an isobaric (constant pressure) process from V2 to V1 at pressure P1.

premise: Segment DA represents an isobaric (constant pressure) process from V2 to V1 at pressure P1.
conclusion: Work done in segment DA is W_DA = P1 (V2 - V1).

premise: Work done in segments: W_AB = P2 (V2 - V1), W_BC = 0, W_CD = 0, W_DA = P1 (V2 - V1).
conclusion: Net work done over one complete cycle is W_net = W_AB + W_BC + W_CD + W_DA.
